thread.title: The best places in NSW to camp during winter | Travel | Travel News and Holiday Deals | |
thread.title_full: The best places in NSW to camp during winter | Travel | Travel News and Holiday Deals | | The Advertiser

author: David Fitzsimons Best Weekend
title: The best places in NSW to camp during winter | Travel | Travel News and Holiday Deals | |
text:
ANNA Alvarez and her young family are having some close encounters with the wildlife.
The Spanish holiday-makers are touring NSW, currently staying in Lane Cove National Park.
“There have been possums, bush turkeys, kookaburras at six o’clock in the morning and rainbow parrots on the table,” she says.
Her son, Einar, 10, got an even bigger surprise.
“I saw a redback. It was next to the wheels,” he says pointing to the camper they are touring in.
Anna, a photographer, says: “We have been travelling around NSW and Victoria for three months.
“Now we have been in Sydney for one-and-a-half months. At first we were in a tent but it was just too difficult to travel with kids in a tent so we bought a second-hand camper. It’s much easier.”
She and husband Ivo, an IT worker, are among a steady stream of tourists, backpackers and locals discovering that winter camping really is possible in NSW given our gorgeous sunny winter days — and a portable heater.
“With kids we really need a heater,” Alvarez says.
“This park is beautiful. It’s amazing, it’s so near to the city. Every day we go for a walk here.”
And the kids love exploring the park.
“They think it is amazing, they like it here.”
Her only concern is that it’s about the only campground close to the centre of Sydney.
“There is not so much to choose from in Sydney. There are no other possibilities. I couldn’t find another one.”
The family has stayed at campgrounds at Bega, Tathra, along the Murray River and in the outback around Broken Hill.
Yannick Gouri and Sarah Williams at Lane Cove River Tourist Park. Picture: Bob Barker. Source: News Corp Australia
Lane Cove River Tourist Park spokesman Yannick Gourvil says sunny, dry days, site availability and quieter campsites make winter camping viable.
“July is the driest month of the year,” he says. “The park is less crowded now, you don’t have people and kids running around as you would in summer.”
That also means more chance to stay in the park’s secluded $200 a night Tandara site — a luxury motel room masquerading as a permanently erected tent complete with its own bathroom, lighting and cooking facilities — that has recently been given a facelift.
Gourvil says: “We find that as you get into the three months of June, July and August it does really drop off. We don’t get the same level of bookings.”
But, he says, many people stay in the park in winter.
“You get a lot of overseas backpackers. And the grey nomads, the people travelling around Australia, are popping in here because it is the closest one to Sydney.”
There are other campgrounds and caravan parks in Sydney at Mascot, Dural, Narrabeen and The Basin (on the Hawkesbury River) and hundreds spread around the state suitable for winter escapes where campfires, cosy sleeping bags and a hot cuppa from a
boiling billy will cast off the winter blues.
NSW Caravan and Camping Industry Association CEO Lyndel Gray says camping is a year-round experience but with cabins, pre-erected tents and on-site vans at many parks, it is within most families’ reach in winter.
“You’ve got less people, the parks are less crowded in winter. There are also great deals going this time of year,” she says. “The outback is great, the climate is good this time of year. On the north and south coasts the whales are migrating, you might even see one.
“The weather is not a deterrent. You can have crisp, cool mornings but bright blue sunny days; it’s great this time of year.
Nothing beats a campfire in winter. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
“There are many places you can have a fire, get rugged up, sit around a fireplace.
“A lot of our parks are right on the beachfront and up close to national parks.”
Gray says some parks offer winter deals that allow kids to stay for free.
“I think camping is something that every kid should experience. I just think that those experiences are priceless. I encourage families to give it a go. These days the equipment is so good you’ve got all the comforts of home anyway.”
She says camping offers experiences most kids will never get inside their home or even in their backyard.
“Smelling nature, waking up to the sounds of the bush or at the beach waking up and hearing the waves.
“Seeing the wildlife, seeing kangaroos,” she says.
There is also the experience of marshmallows toasted on an open fire. “I think bacon and eggs toasted on the barbecue is pretty hard to beat.”
Gray says the new friendships that are forged when families make friends in the campground environment are some of the best.
But what are the risks of children being injured by being over-adventurous in the bush?
“Kids will be kids, but it is an environment that’s safe to an extent,” she says.
Follow David Fitzsimons on Twitter: @FitzAtLarge
PACK YOUR SWAG
Great places to stay for year-round camping throughout the state
CITY
● Lane Cove River Tourist Park, Plassey Rd, North Ryde; nationalparks.nsw.gov.au
Camp in a secluded bush setting minutes from a railway station and only 12km from the CBD. Choose from the Tandara glamping tent, caravans and campsites.
Camp in style in Lane Cove National Park. Picture: Bob Barker. Source: News Corp Australia
● The Basin Campground, Ku-ring-gai Chase National Park, Pittwater; nationalparks.nsw.gov.au/camping-and-accommodation/campgrounds/The-Basin-campground
Getting there is half the fun as you travel across Pittwater and into Coasters Retreat on a small ferry. You camp beside steep hills at this popular spot that has 400 sites.
The ferry wharf at The Basin in Pittwater. Picture: John Fotiadis Source: News Limited
OUTBACK
● Warrawong On The Darling, Barrier Hwy, Wilcannia; warrawongonthedarling.com.au
Camping and caravan complex with new facilities just out of Wilcannia. Ideal stop-off on an outback trip from Dubbo to Broken Hill.
● Kinchega National Park, Menindee-Broken Hill Rd, Menindee; nationalparks. nsw.gov.au/visit-a-park/parks/Kinchega-National-Park
Throw a fishing line in the Darling, explore the historic woolshed and go for bushwalks in this outback wonderland.
NORTH
● Bonny Hills, Ocean Dve, Bonny Hills; northcoastholidayparks.com.au/park/info/bonny-hills
A great place to spot with ocean views when visiting Port Macquarie. Choose from luxury cabins, glamping-style beach tents and caravan and camping sites.
Bonny Hills Holiday Park Port Macquarie. Picture: Destination NSW Source: Supplied
● Stockton Beach Holiday Park, 3 Pitt St, Stockton; stocktonbeach.com
With access to more than 30km of sandy beaches, ocean views and only being minutes from the centre of Newcastle and great coffee shops it is an ideal winter escape.
An aerial view of the holiday park at Stockton Beach. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
SOUTH
● Big 4 Narooma Easts Holiday Park, Princes Hwy, Narooma; eastsnarooma.com.au
Cabins, van spaces and campsites on the Wagonga inlet are an ideal place for a south coast break. Take the oceanfront bikepath to Dalmeny or a boat over to scenic Montague Island which is sensational for whale and seal spotting.
Narooma Big 4 Easts Holiday Park. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
● Sapphire Sun Eco Holiday Village, 441 Princes Hwy, Eden; sapphiresun.com.au
Cabins, van and campsites front Twofold Bay on the historic Killer Whale Trail. Check out the area’s whale history and get ready to spot the thousands of whales returning south this month.
Kids at Billabong Camp at Dubbo Western Plains Zoo. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
TREAT YOURSELF
● Taronga Western Plains Zoo, Obley Rd, Dubbo; taronga.org.au/taronga-western-plains-zoo
Camp out with the animals in tents, cabins or in the Savannah lodge at Dubbo’s safari park. It’s not cheap but with behind the scenes tours and other extras included it can be the highlight of your winter camping trip.
CHILL OUT
● Wee Jasper Camping & Recreation Grounds, Wee Jasper; weejasperreserves.com.au
Here’s one for the hardy willing to endure some seriously chilly nights. The pay-off is a campsite in one of the prettiest locations in NSW, in the hills between Yass and Canberra with a great river for fishing and stunning underground caves nearby. A great chance to have a roaring campfire.
M ORE INFORMATION
caravan-camping.com.au and nationalparks.nsw.gov.au
Originally published as The best places to camp in winter
